Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

div.head: THE MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
div.p: An important announcement appears in this morning’s telegrams in regard to the Morocco Conference, which, it is to be hoped, will have a reassuring effect on Europe. The Cologne Gazette, which has often been employed to convey important information by the Imperial Government, ridicules the idea of war resulting should the Conference prove abortive, and declares that the status quo will be maintained even if all the debates at Algeciras end in a fiasco. A Renter« telegram from Berlin declares that the article is inspired, and if so, its publica-tion it evidently due to a desire of the Berlin Government to remove the existing very general distrust of German diplomacy.

It may be, of course, that there is no ground for pessimism, and that both Count Tattenbach and Herr von Radowitz have received instructions to be oonciliatory ; bat the history of the Moroccan dispute so far does not encourage sanguine anticipations. Until it is known exactly what claims Germany advances, there can be no certainty that the Conference will not fail. One thing, however, is assured, Great Britain is in thorough agreement with the French claims, and throughout the Conference it will be the duty of our representative to support M. Revoil; in the unhappy event of an arrangement not being arrived at, the British Government will still be ready to assist France in whatever way is needful to secure justice. This, we take it is generally understood in Europe and it is now realised that any hopes that have been built on the present change of Administration at home, and a consequent vacillation on of policy, are unfounded.

Up to now there has been much talk of conciliation and of the entirely pacific inten-tions of Germany, such amiable assurances having bean freely provided by the German Press. Unfortunately, however, there is nothing to show that the German representatives at the Conference have received instructions of a really conciliatory nature. On the contrary, there has hitherto been no abatement in the insistence of the German inspired Press on the necessity of internationalising' the Moroccan police, excepting that on the Algerian frontier.” That proposal will be resisted by Prance and the Powers which will act with her. These Powers, as we know, are England, Russia, Italy, and, in all probability. 8pain and the United States. Against such a combination Germany will be powerless, and she will have either to submit or to upset the card table by a gesture of impatience which might have the most serious consequences to the world's peace. It would appear, however, from the announcement which the Berlin Government has made through the Cologne Gazette that Germany has decided to submit.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: TIME CONCENTRATION MARCH. Owing to the Bairam Holidays, the troops of the Egyptian Army will not be able to join in a field day during the ensuing week. In place of the usual weekly field day the troops of the Army of Occupation will be exercised t> morrow in a Time Concentration March, under the following scheme

Abbassia.—M.I., M.M.P., 1st Bn. K.R.R. Corps, with 1 maohiue gun, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 8 a.m. They will march t j the Abattoir from which point they will be lei to the Citadel (Inner Square opposite the Officers Mess), by an Intelligence Officer detailed by the General Officer Commanding. The M.M.P. will atop in the Outer Square

Kaar-e.-Nil.— 2nd Co, R R 2nd Bn. Royal Instilling Fusiliers, with 8 machine guns, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 9 a m., and will be led to the Inner Square. Citadel, as above
Citadel.—R G A with 2 15-pr. guns 2nd Bn. Royal Berk-*. Regt., will parade under orders from the Commandant in the Outer Square, Citadel, opposite the Guard Room, at 10 a.m.
After the troops have met at the rendezvous they will form into three columns as follows: -

let Column (Outer 8quare) to march off at 10 20 am. - R G. A., 2nd Bo Royal Berkshire Regiment under the command of Major R. Percy-Smith. R.G.A., will be led to the second place of rendezvous as above. 2nd Column (Officer's Me Square) to march off at 10.35 a.m.—M.l. 1st Bn , KRR Corps
UNDER THE COMMAND OF LT COL CJ MARKAM 1st Bn. KRR Corps, will be led to the 2nd place of rendezvous as above.
The object of the exercise is to concentrate definite place at a definite time.

The Bishop's Visit to Egypt,

Bishop Byh. Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem and the East arrives at Port Said and proceed to Cairo on Wednesday next. His Lordship will visit Alexandria from February 17-19 and on Sunday the 18th inst., will officiate at 8t. Mark’s, Alexandria, and All Saint’s, Ramleh. Millionaire Dies at Cairo.

Thomas J. Emery, the multi-millionaire of Cincinnati, who has died in Cairo, was on his tenth trip to Africa and his fiftieth trip to Europe. Mr. Emery was a patron of the arts, and noted for his philanthropy. He was notably generous in aid of Booker T. Washington's educational work.
Renta at Alexandria.

An Arabic contempoary publishes an article advocating the dredging and restoration of the port of Damieta as a panacea for the extortionate increases of rents in Alexandria. The argument is that if Dami-tta was restored to its ancient prosperity the surplus population of Alexandria would be drawn thither, thereby decreasing the demaod for houses here.

A Pspyru* Find.

An old Egyptian papyrus has recently been acquired in Cairo which contained a commentary on Plato. This has jast been published by the eminent German phdolognt Hermann Dietshs. The document is anonymous, hot experts refer the writing to about the second oentury and are disposed to refer it to Gaios and bi* aobool. The papyrus is described a* being of deep interest for ad concerned in the st oHy of Plato’s writings and theories. In one party of the text rrference is m *de to a second proem of the Dialogue, which he ancients h«’d to be apocryphal, though ly modern it is held to be one of Plato’s earlier writings.

div.head: CONDITION OF PARTIES
div.p: LONDON. Monday.

The disruption of the Unionist Party is the great topic of conversation in the clubs and in he City. According to the latest estimates the Cbsmberlainite party will consist of about a hundred members, while Mr. Balfour's followers, who have remained faithful to him,will only number fifty. This calculation is only a rough one.

The cause of the disruption was Mr. Cham herlain’s failure to induce t**e late Prime Minister to adopt a strenuous policy iu opposi tion. As to the leadership nothing will probably be settled until the Speaker has been e’eotel. In the meantime Mr. Akers Douglas is the emoorary leader.

The Times dismisses the oontingsnoy of Mr, Waltsr Longs leadership or any other third party as au utter impossibility with two much stronger men behind, and remarks that, if Mr. Chamberlaiu takes the leadership, »h* Unionist pary will simply btc me a Tarifl Reform party aud the party quA Umonist lOuld practically oease to exist

div.p: (FROM OUR 8PECIAL CORRESPONDENT.)

Ou the arrival of the “Dakablieh” atSoskin the 'twenty four,” ss the combined foroes of Initiators and journalists are called in an official document reorntly typewritten at Khartoum, got on board the 3 G S. “Piinoes” and went round the ha'bour. div.head: PORT SUDAN
div.p: At this point a few words shout Saakin aud Port Sndau may ba of interest The firmer town is bWed with a vile climate and a poor harbour with a very difficult entrance. It* water supply is not magnificent and the native town thoash now kept fairly clean is not healthy. Port Sudan ha* a decidedly good hubour. The entrance is fairly easy and should be safa enough when the system of lights projected by Lieut Drury R. N, complete. Its water supply is so far ot>ly moderately good bat it is believed that the artisian well now being constructed will supply all the teeds of the town in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. The olimate ha* not been tested so long as that of Saakin bat is believed to he drier iu sammer. It was certainly agreeable enough during the 24 hours of our iUy. The immediate hinterland is cerra n’y more barren and useless-looking than the Saakin plain which only requires water to make it productive and is, Lear the railway at any rate, leas stiny and sandy. But any advantage* that Suakin possesses areooonterbalaooed by Port Sudan’s admirable harbour.

div.head: THE NEW HARBOUR
div.p: The eutranoe, as already stated is not hard to negotiate. About a third of a mile op the harbour P forks. One branch which may be called the Western forms a basin where a man of war can anchor and it soon shoal* while the 01 her hranoh, the Northern or the Eastern, run* inland for about 3 miles from the harbour mouth. Its average depth for the greater part of this distance is from 13 to 14 fathoms, shoaling to from 3 to 4 fathoms at the N. eod. Iu breadth it nowhere much exceeds a quarter of a mile, there are no rooks and all that the harbour requires is a row of quays and a supply of light* each of which it is promised. At present temporary quay* are being obstructed oo the N E. bank about a mile at most from by stone quays 12 of which are projected, e*ch capable of berthing a good sited man of war commencing at the 8heikh’s tomb near the t itranoe and following the N.B bank for the beet part of a mile. The potential capacity of the harbour can be judged from this and with twelve Urge ships berthed seourely there would be room for several other smaller vessels if seourely anchored by the stern near the basin. At present there is swinging room for only one large veatel but fifteen—perhaps twenty—could lie io the harbour if properly seourrd from their sterns. The Commeroial Railway Station and Caetom* will be on the same side of the channel a* the tags, while on the opposite shore the Government buildings and Quarantine Station have been already commenced.

div.head: The Port's Light
div.p: The lighting of the port will be very complete. The 8anganeib Lighthoaie with its range of 25 miles will show the approaches to the harbour at the Sheikh’s tomb, which is the most prominent landmark. At the entraooe will be a fixed m'ght with a range of 14 miles white with two red sections bearing over the dangerous reefs known as Towartit and Wingate reefs. Further up will be two lights each of six miles minimum range—one green on the starboard band and one red to port. The guiding lights will be mounted olear of all the town- lights. in two pairs.esoh pair io a wooden towsr of at least ’ 35 feet io height while the sides of each tower will ke painted red and whi e in horizontal baud* as daylight mark*.

div.head: ROUTES
div.p: We started too late in the day to see mnob mote than the silhouettes of the mountains behind Handout throngh which the line passes, but the view of tbuir peak* from the Saakin plain was very fine The plain itVf was covered with gr*s* and scrub, with melon patches and com for the fimt few mile* sfter Suakin We pa**e t Geheit, whore L^rd Cromer's. are rather rare iu the immediate neighbourhood of the line now-a-days, but at a short distance from it they ooour in numbers and we saw three oommon gatelles and an ariel with some sandgrouee from our train. The journty was hot and dusty, but heat is relative. 80 degrees seems tropioal after Cairo’s 65% or 70 % average maximum in January, but in summer the working pertiee noted 128 % on one occasion and the day temperature averaged a figure that would appal a European. The wonderful dryness of the air, however, made it far more tolerable than might have been expected

div.head: The Journey to Khartoum
div.p: At El Hudi the sorob beg* n to grow thick and palms showed us that we were nearing the river. Suon we teached Atbara which is the Crewe ar.d Clapham Junction of the Sodan Railways. Any amount of work is going on here and it w.d not be long before Half* lo*es its pride of plaoe to the Atbara work-hops.

I hen to Mutmar and Sbe»di north of which we pasted some 25 pyramids of the B hioptan rules of Meroe, on which BimbashiLoM gave us such information at could be given. Thou on- w«rds till night fell through open woods of sunt with cultivation only on the Nile bankin a tiny strip* At about 9.30 p.m. we reaobed Khartoum and our experiences there most he dealt with separately. I can only here say that we are experiencing the utmost kindness and hospitality.

div.head: DEATH OF SIR COOKSON
div.p: The many friends of the late Consul-General at Alexandria will regret to learn that Sir Charles Cookson died at his home at Chelsea on Saturday.

Sir Charles Alfred Cookson, K.C.M.G., C.B., was born in 1829. He graduated in second class Clasrioal H moors at Oriel College, Oxford, in 1855, and was called to the Bar at the loser Temple, January 26, 1867. He was appointed Law Secretary and Chanoellier, with

Royal Commission as Vioe-Consal to the Supreme Consular Court at Constantinople, Jnly 6.1868. While there the oelebrated Marathon brigandage case oooarred and he was sent to Athens to investigate the charges against the Greek brigands concerned in the murders of Mr. Herbert and the other Englishmen.

Sir Charles was appointed Consul aud Jadge at Alexandria, November 30, 1874 and was Acting Agent and Consul General from May 26 till October 14, 1875 ; from May 20 till Ootober, 6. 1876 ; from October 6 till November 23, 877 ; from August 1 till October 28, 1880 ; aud from May 4 to September 19, 188L Sir Charles was employed in Cyprus as Legal Adviser and afterwards as Member of the Ex- entire Council and Judicial Commissioner from Augast, 1878, till March 1879. He was 2nd Delegate oo the Commission at Cairo from December 16, 1880, to April 23,18d1;aod from March 10 to May 17,1884. On November 28, 1881 he was made a C.B. He was Brit sh Delegate on the International Com min ion for Egyptian Indemnities, from January, 1888. to March, 18^4.
He bsoune Consul-General at Alexandria on Janoary 1st, 1891 and retired from that post in August 1897. He was made a K.C.M.G. in 1888.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Archdake and Archdaobess Otto of Austria left Khartoam oa Priday afternoon oa their way to Egypt
They were seen off at Ha’fay a station by Slatin Pasha. _____

The dababieh in which Princess Looise and the Duke of Argyll ore sailing op the Nile a most dainty affair. The vessel has been freshly paintel and redecorated for the voyage. Green, white, and heliotrope are the prevailing ooloars of the saloon. The little drawing room leading from the saloon is deliciooriy famished with Oriental carpets, cushions, divans, and graceful hangings. The dining room is in the form of a cosy lounge at the stem of the boat All the cabins are in white and gold ; those occupied by the distinguished travellers have windows on either side, so that none of the desert landscape is missed. Gaily coloured awnings are spread over the upper deok. One of the bast chefs in Egypt is sailing with the Duke and Duchess to provide a table in keeping with the rest of the appointments. The trip constitutes a record of luxury in Nile travel. The Bari ot Loudesborough, who is sxpeetsd to arrive in Cairo about the middle of this mouth and has taken rooms at the Savoy Hotel, is the eldest son of the first Earl and Lady Edith Franoes Wilbelmina Somerset, yocbgest daughter of the 7th Duke of Beaufort, K.G. He saooeeded his father in 1900 and a considerable amount of property in Yorkshire and Line losbire, including the beaotifal Loudesboroogh estates near'Scarborough. Iu 1887 he married Lady Grace Augusta Pane, eldest daughter of the 12th Earl of Westmoreland, end he has two sons and one daughter. He is Deputy-Lieu tenant f the East Riding of Yorkshire, a late Lieutenant of the Yorkshire Hussars, and Honorary Cqlooel of the 2CH1 Volunteer Battalion Bast Yorkshire Regiment. His eldest eon and faeir is Visooent Raindiffe, who is only in h;s fourteenth year.

Crookshaok Pacha arrives at Pashoda this afternoon from Gondokoro. Hit Excellency is doe at Khartoum on the l(hb and at Cairo I on the 17th inst.The latest arrivals at the Grand Hotel Khartoam inolode Count Philippo Maraz- tint, Italy ; Herr Okerleutcant Lucas, sheriff of Cheshire. Both be and Mrs. Hornby Lewis are well-known figures in London and entertain a great deal when they are in their pretty hoote in Pont 8tiett. Tbeir country seat is Marbory Hall, Cheshire. Mr. aud Mrs. and Miss Lea Smith are leaving Cairo on Tuesday for a short trip to Upper Egypt. They will return to Shepheards about the end of the month. LONDON, February 3.

The "Standard” says that Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain dined together yesterday evening and discussed the future of the party. During the afternoon Mr. Chamberlain had conferred with the Committee of Liberal Unionists on the same subject, and on Thur - day Mr. Balfour consulted with his most intimate followers.

The "Standard” declares that unless Mr. Balfour accepts Mr. Chamberlain’s general tariff policy, his leadership of a united party will be gone for ever. As Mr. Chamberlain will not accept the leadership of a divided party, his followers will then form an independent organisation. The only alternative would be to afford another leader, say, Mr. Walter Lorg, an opportunity of giving party unity.
It is not yet decided whether the Liberals will oppose Mr. Balfour’s candidature in the City. (Reuter)
LONDON, February 4.
The "Observer” states that Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain parted in discord on Friday. The Opposition will therefore be split into two groups. (Reuter)

div.head: The Assouan Ball
div.p: (FROM A CORRESPONDENT).
Assouan, January 30.

The fancy dress dance held at the Cataract Hotel last night was voted a great success. But in recording any success there are surely one or two minor points of adverse criticism that are always worthy of mention if a report of an event of this kind is to be in any way of the nature of a criticism.
This being granted let us take our two minor points and have done with them !

The most unmusical dancer present oould hardly fail to have observed the lamentable lack of time on the part of the band which went far to spoil the whole evening’s enjoy¬ment The instrumentalists appeared to believe that they were giving ns a concert, and that if any of the audience oared to dance to their music they only had themselves to blame ! Our other point is the result of the voting for the best fancy dresses for ladies and gentlemen. Out of many beautiful and excellent costumes, a lady who had the hardihood to blank her face and appear as a Cook’s dragoman before natives and Berberine servants was singled out by the majority of voters as the wearer of the best get-up in the room. It was undoubtedly clever, but rather made one shudder than feel pleased under the circumstances. Still more remarkable was the selection of a most incoc- guous so-called mandarin for the gentleman’s prise. This mandarin wore a Chinaman’s hat that was not a mandarin’s, he wore a clergy¬man’s collar, a mandarin’s coat hired from an Indian for the evening, and shoes that were anything bat those of a Chinaman I ! He also wore a very English face which bore no attempts at a Chinese "make up.

Of the ladies we thought that a charming Swiss peasant-girl, the recognised "belle of the ball,” carried off the palm. A Spanish dress and a Moorish dress were also very much ad¬mired. To come to the gentlemen, the clever impersonation of a lady effected by our popu¬lar organist here succeeded in deceiving us all, and was quite the event of the evening. Next to this we admired a very handsome Direotoire costume greatly, the coat we understand is ori ginal. A benevolent looking and rather corpu¬lent tourist with a wonderful umbrella and a still more wonderful insect on his helmet was a very clever get-up, but it proved too much for the wearer who returned to his normal self after a couple of dance. A costume from Veronique, and an ordinary native dress are worthy of note, this last being very effec¬tive as the wearer appeared to have the graceful, swinging step of the Arab which carried off his black, flowing "galabiya” very well.
In a word, with the exception of the music, a most enjoyable evening was spent and the management are to be congratulated on the result of the evening.

This company was formed in December, 1897, for the purpose of acquiring the business of Messrs. Walker and Co., of Cairo, as from the 1st May, 1897, and that of Messrs. C. G. Meimarachi and Co., Cairo, as from 1st July 1897. The original capital of the Company WAS £250,000, divided into 25,000 6 1/2 per cent. Preference Shares of £5 each, and 25,000 Ordinary Shares of £6 each, of which latter only

15,000 Shares were issued. increasing £1 each, Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., is now the moat important kind in Egypt as Army Contractors, Wine and Spirit Merchants, Provision Dealers, Drapers, Milliners, and Silk and General Merchants, having important Agencies and Sob Agencies a large number of the principal leading English, French, German, Italian, and Austrian manufacturing houses doing business in Egypt. The financial prosperity of Egypt during the last few years has improved beyond all anticipation, and its continuance is regarded as an established fact. Of recent years the agriculture of the country has developed, railways have been completed, districts hitherto inaccessible to trade have been opened op, and insignificant villages in a few years have developed into prosperous and thriving towns, with the resalt that the purchasing power of the ever increasing population has led to a growing demand for European manufactures and commodities. Owiog to the extensive business experience and influence of its Executive in Egypt, the Company is in a position to continue to command an increasing volume in every department of native and European trade. Owing to the recent development in trade in Egypt, the Company’s premises were found to be inadequate to cope with the growth of its business. During the last few years the centre of the trade of Cairo has changed, and what was convenient at the time of the forma¬tion of the Company has recently become unsuited to its customers. The Directors, realising the necessity for meeting these altered conditions, have purchased certain land situate in the fashionable Ismailieh quarter of Cairo. The purchase price of the property is L.E. 72,247.800 and the report of Mr. Henry Hinks (Messrs. Barclay Hinks and Co. Cairo) a member of the Suveyors Institution, London dated the 16th of January 1906, in respect to its value when acquired and present value is as follows. . ‘‘I have an inspection of the property lately purchased by you at the junction of Charia El Manakh and Charia El Madabegh in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo at the price of LB. 72,247. “The property is of an area of 4816.5 square metres, of a rectangular shape and through its central position in the European business and residential quarter, it undoubtedly provides one of the finest and most suitable sites in Cairo for the erection of yoor new buildings. .“In my opinion the present value of this property is ninety six thousand, three hundred and thirty pounds Egyptian (L.E. 96330,) or £20 per square metre. still amount greatly exceeds, your purchase price; the value of land in this quarter is still rising, and a farther increase may be expected should the new Bourse be erected, as is intended, on a site in the immediate vicinity." .. The Directors have arranged with Nungovich Bey for placing £100,000 5 per, cent Mortgage Debentures and the amount produced from these Debentures and the present issue (which has already been guaranteed by Nungovich Bey) will provide the necessary funds for the purchase of the land and the erection of suitable buildings thereon, in addition to providing further working capital for the Company. No deferred Shares have been issued, and after payment of the Preference Dividend amounting to £8,125 per annum, provision for Interest on Debentures reserve, depreciation, etc., the balance of profit is available for dividend to the holders of ordinary Shares. Perusal of the following returns based upon the Company’s published accounts and Balance Sheets, duly certified by Messrs. W. B. div.head: CORRESPONDENCE- LES ELECTIONS
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de 1’“Egyptian Gazette.’

Voua avez déjà, lors des dernières élections insisté sur la défectuosité de la loi électorale mun c'pale d’Alexandrie Les électeurs dont le nornhie est excessivement restreint sont porïr la plupart des gens d’affaires qui n’ont pas le loisir de s’occuper des questions municipales ou des dé œovrés, qui s’en désintéressent oom- p’ètement. Le votes des uns et des autres sont acquis d’avance non pas au bon candidat, hon¬nête et intelligent, mais au plus plat, au pins incapable, au plus véreux. Le droit pour le commerce d’élire la moitié des conseillers est également un abus incompréhensible : ne dirait- on pas qn’Alexandrie est une simple faotorerie du Congo ou de la Côte d’ivoire ?

Tant que notre ville sera soumise à la loi électorale existante, les personnalités honoia blés et capables seront tenues à l’écart affaires municipales au grand profit des ar rivistes et des tripoteurs.

A cet égard le passé est une leçon : les membres actuels du oonseil munioipal ne se font remarquer ni par leur lèle, ni par leurs aptitudes, ni par Jour déair de servir les intérêts du public. Parmi ceux qui sortent à la fin de ce mois, il en est qui n’ont jamais ouvert la bouche,d’autres qui n’ont assisté qu’à quelques rares séances, d’autres enfin qui n’ont fait un peu de bruit que pour leurs intérêts personnels ou leur gloriole.

Ceux qui vont les remplacer seront-ils meil leurs 7 Auoun personnage sérieux ne s’est en-core mis sur les rangs et oelà se conçoit : est difficile, pour ne pas dire impossible, à un bon o^ndidat de se faire élire, sans s’abaisser à des procédés peu recommandables.

Dans ces conditions la., ville d’Alexandrie peut attendre longtemps ses réformes : surveil lance des marchés, contrô'e des poids et me sures, assainissement public, baisse des loyers, service du balayage et de l’arrosage, canalisa¬tion des rues. Tout cela ne vieudra pas desitô Nos édiles présents et futurs ont d’autres sou¬cis : ÜB* ont acheté des terrains dans un empla cernent désert et ils s’occupent d’y faire passer une rue ou mieux encore une ligne de tram way ; ils ont pris des aotions d’une sooiété et ils s’efforcent de faire accorder une concession à cette Eooiété, etc. etc. Pour cela il n’y besoin ni de disoours, ni d’études, ni de dévoue¬ment : il suffit de voter : C’est le "struggle for life” au palais munioipal.
Le jour où les Alexandrins voudront ore gestion loyale et désintéressée ils devront faire modifier la loi électorale ou reoverser la Muni-cipalité. ’ A.G.

div.head: SUCRERIES ET RAFFINERIE D’EGYPTE
div.p: Il ressort de l’état comparé des cannes tra-vaillée au 29 janvier 1906, par les Suoreries, que 193 journées de travail dans les usines de Matai, Abon Eonrgas, Ermant, Mat ma, Nag- Hamadi, Cheikh Fadl, ont permis de travailler 288,754 tonnes de cannes, soit une moyenne générale de 7,733 par jour. Or l’exeroice de 194 a donné 258,250 tonnes pendant 216 journées de travail, soit une moyenne de 7,7 4 tonnes par jour. Encore faut-il ajouterque dans cette période de 1905-1906, l’usine de Bibeh n’a pas fonctionné. Ainsi avec 23 journées de travail en moins et 1 usine arrêtée, le total de la canne travaillée n’a pas baissé.
Cela prouve que la nouvelle administration peut réaliser des économies sensibles, sans prë¥ judioe pour la production.

Par ordonnance de jeudi, rendue par le pré-sident Tuck, M. John Home, directeur de 1A National Bank of Eeypt, a éfé nommé contrôleur des Sucreries ef lUffinerie d’E/ypte en rempla cernent de Sir Elwin Palmer, décédé.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA "ANTAR.”
div.p: Ün nombreux publio assistait samedi soir à la première représentation de cette tragédie qui a, comme l’on sait, obtenu un grand succès au Caire.
Le sujet, emprunté à la légende arabe, ne se prêtait guère à une œuvre théâtrale M. Chekri Ganem a cependant réussi à en faire ni e bonne adaptation.

La figure du héros-poète est fort bien des-sinée. Les personnages conservent jusqu’au bont de la pièce leur caractère national ; leur language, plein de métaphores empruntées au style du temps, est empreint d’une vive imagi¬nation orientale.

Un des prinoipaux mérites de l’auteur est, en effet, d’avoir reproduit en de beaux vers fran¬çais toute la saveur de la littérature arabe. Le dia'ogne d amour avec Abla au 4me acte est l’un des plus beaux passages de l'œuvre.
L auditoire, composé en grande partie de syriens, a fait une véritable fête à l’auteur, Chékri Gmem, qui ada se présenter plusieurs fois sur la scène.

div.head: DECES
div.p: Noos avons le regret d’annoDcer la mort de MADAME CATHERINE TREHAKI, dé Hée hier an Caire.
1,8 cortège funèbre partira aujourd'hui de la Gare du Caire à 3 heures p.m. précises pour se rendre directement au cimetière.
Nous adressons à la famille éplorée nos senti méats sincères de condoléance.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny- NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Caire, 8 février.

Le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié hier à Londres à 90 1/2. L’Unifiée a monté de 1/4 à 105. La National Bank est renseignée en nou¬velle hausse de 3/8 à 27 3/8, la Daira de 1/4 à 17 5/8. etl’Agrioole, inchangée, à 9 8/4.
A Paris, l’aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien a haussé de 8 francs à 808. La Banque d’Athènes
a réactionné de 2 francs à 136.

Notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, assez animé, avec tendanoe ferme an début. Après la hausse exceptionnelle des deux dernières séanoes, notamment sur la National Bank, on ponvait, à bon droit, s’attendre à une réotion très prononcée. Elle ne s’est pourtant guère produite, ce qui tend à montrer que le mouvement ascensionnel s’accentuera aprèB un recnl forcé.
La National Bank a ouvert à 27 7/16 pour olôtnrer à 3/* 6. L’Agricole a débnté à 9 29/32 pour finir à 13/16.

Bon mouvement sur le Comptoir Financier, q i a atteint 4 15/16 et surtout sur le Wardan rEitate, qui a encore gagné, à 7 1/8, une 1/2 livre sur le oours de la veille. A ce prix il y avait enoore acheteurs, indice qne la hausse est appelée à s’accentuer.
L’action Crédit Foncier a olôturé entre 807- 808 en bonne tendanoe. Les obligations à lots 18k6 ont remonté à 335 ; les nouvelles restent à 274-275.
L’Improvements Corporation s’est inscrite à 4 13/16.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovioh ont avancé à 13 3/4-13/16. Les Baehler se maintiennent fermes à 4 1/4 et l’on pressent an très proobe mouvement sur œ titre.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Cotton Mills o it été très recherchés et ont atteint 6 sh. 3. O i prévoit oaoours bien plus élevé, d’ailleurs jastifié par les raisons que nous avons exoo*ées dans notre Circulaire du 13 Janvier dernier. Les Sait ont olôturé à 23 sh. vendeurs. Les Markets ont fait 25 sh. 6.
Nous extrayons d’une lettre de Londres, en iate du 27 janvier, le passage suivant relatif à la situation monétaire :

"Malgré les nouvelles favorables de Berlin de New-York et d’ailleurs, la Banque d’Angle-terre oontinae à renforcer sa situation en ac-caparant tout le disponible qu’elle peut trouver sur le marohé. Il en résnlte que le loyer de l’argent reste ioi très tenda. Il faut payer plus de 4 % pour les prêta au joar le jour, au-de’à de 3 3/4 pnnr lu oonrt terme et le t*nx de l’escompte libre reste entre 3 3/4 et 3 7/8. Le numéraire est toujours assez abondant, mais pour en obtenir il faut y mettre le pr x. On oroit que même si la Banque oesse d’agir sur le marché, oelui-oi ne retrouvera pas facilement une aisance prononcée à cause de l’activité des affaires." I !
Nous avons annoncé que l’assemblée géné-rale du Crédit Foncier Egyptien a aoprouvé le* comptes de l’exeroioa clos le 31 Octobre 1905 et décidé la distribntioa d’un dividende de 15 franos par aotion.

Ce dividende sera payé, à partir du 20 oou- rant, sur la présentation du ooupon N* 26, aux anciennes aotions Nos 1 à 200,000 seulement, les actions nouvelles. Nos 200.001 à 400.00D, ayant été émises avec jouissance du 1er No-vembre 1905.
Le dividende de 171 franos par part de fon-dateur (on de Frs. 17,10 par dixième de part) sera également payé à partir du 20 oourant sur présentation du coupon N° 9.

Cette réduction de prix ayant étédéoidée par la Sooiété dans le seul bot d’en faire pn fiter les habitants de la Ville, le pablio est prié de veiller à œ que la dire réduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui Garnissent l’eau, afin de ne pas laisser oes derniers profiter du rabais qui n’a été oonsenti qu’en faveur du publia

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: TheE0£Pttatt(3a3ette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in .Jpril and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will w*ant to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list snowing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe. They are as follows :— The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton,London or Liverpool--occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :— Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days Alexandria to Messina 3 „ PortSaid or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 „ Alexandria toVenice and Trieste... 4 „ ‘Alexandria to Naples 3 „ Port Said to Genoa 5 „ Port Said to Naples 4 „ Alexandria to Constantinople ... 4 , Alexandria to Piraeus 2 „ Port Said to Gibraltar 7 „ The steamers, of the P. & 0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers arc largely patronised by travellers to Egypt. As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4£ hours. The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg. The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria. As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free On the railways of Europe, but there are I several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt wjio undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris” and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as Port Said, soon as possible after receiving the Indian. j mails from the" great} liner arrived ' from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the “Ferry boats,” having been specially built to carry, the British mail from Port Said to i Brindisi. If you are going' straight through to England yo will find the train waiting at | Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should 1 arrive in Londoh on the fifth day from leaving Pnrf So,VI

div.head: SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the mo»t charming and popular places on the island. Giardwi is lie station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormipa is most delightful, occupying*) about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.c. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain-his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Givoannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal, Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the N6rth German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rnbattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive tool will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote aTj least one week to ^siting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to~need comrneilt here. Leaving the Eternal City with maoh regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the Cite/ oj Flowers and its snrrouhding country. fn Florenoe itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and oxour sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up throngh the halls a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Eller o, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent tnrongh groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking’ panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. /YlAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Gefcfca. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GFNOA (La Suparba) .—The most | picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with j the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a ‘ phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. The patriarchal home of Italy’s most an-1 eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuarv, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs. From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the to- r of the Lakes. The | Cathedral is tlie principal attraction, with its i beautiful windows illustrating the History of ! the Bible. The*public gardens and the monu- 1 mental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan. San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHRN ITALY
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass ft quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, aud vet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, tlien slowly the 'whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza : Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, ana Mmaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the snore of the lake td Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and- three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as “A cluster of delights and grandeurs.” LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a populatien of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the'Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprinoand M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minfciei*. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town,is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment,” by Ciseri, and ‘The Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Itigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and aronnd the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The L'lkeof Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigij Pilatus, Burgen- stock and Sonnenberg neecnng a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful p^rt of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and fmountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis,* is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from t the Santis to the Motterho>n. THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach and Staubbnch. Then also‘the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summfep^and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be presen• at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.p: Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
